content: The Act titled "Congressional Accountability Act of 1993" is cited as the short title. It applies to the application of the Act. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies laws related to employment terms, health and safety, and employer-employee rights to Congress in the same way as they apply to private individuals and Executive agencies. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 extends laws regarding employment terms, health and safety, and rights of employers and employees to Congress, similar to how they apply to private individuals and Executive agencies. This includes laws such as the Social Security Act, National Labor Relations Act, Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, and Civil Rights Act of 1964. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 extends various laws to Congress, including the Social Security Act, National Labor Relations Act, Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, Civil Rights Act of 1964, Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967, Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, and Rehabilitation Act of 1973. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 extends various laws to Congress, including the Social Security Act, National Labor Relations Act, Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, Civil Rights Act of 1964, Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967, Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, Rehabilitation Act of 1973, Privacy Act of 1974, Age Discrimination Act of 1975, Ethics in Government Act of 1978, and Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 extends various laws to Congress, including the Freedom of Information Act. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 extends the Freedom of Information Act to Congress and applies the Independent Counsel Provisions to certain individuals within Congress. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 extends the Independent Counsel Provisions to certain individuals in Congress, including Senators, Representatives, and employees of Congress. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 extends the Independent Counsel Provisions to certain individuals in Congress, including Senators, Representatives, employees, elected officers, Legislative Counsel, and Capitol Police members. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 extends Independent Counsel Provisions to various individuals in Congress, including employees of either House, elected officers, Legislative Counsel, Capitol Police members, and employees of Congressional instrumentalities. Employees covered under the Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 include those paid by the Secretary of the Senate or the Clerk of the House of Representatives, as well as employees of Congressional instrumentalities such as the Congressional Research Service, the Library of Congress, and the Government Printing Office. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 covers employees of various Congressional entities, including the Office of the Architect of the Capitol, the Botanic Gardens, the Government Printing Office, the Library of Congress, the Congressional Budget Office, and the Copyright Royalty Tribunal. District or State offices of Members are treated as affiliated branches of private employers under the Act. Members may consider political affiliation in certain circumstances. (g) Place of Residence and Political Affiliation.--A Member may consider the political affiliation and place of residence of an individual seeking employment on their personal staff. (h) Conforming Amendment.--Section 509 of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 is repealed. (i) Application of Small Business Exemption to Members.--Certain laws may contain exemptions for Members. The text discusses the consideration of political affiliation and place of residence for individuals seeking employment on a Member's personal staff. PROMULGATION OF IMPLEMENTING REGULATIONS. The House of Representatives and the Senate must create rules within 180 days to implement the Act. Failure to do so will result in being subject to Executive agency regulations. SEC. 4. RIGHT OF APPEAL. SEC. 4. RIGHT OF APPEAL. Individuals affected by actions under this Act can seek review in Federal court with the same rights as private persons under relevant laws.
